hints_html:
Simpson’s Rule in full generality is, for even \(\displaystyle n\),

\(S_{n} = \frac{\Delta x}{3} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 4f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + 4f(x_3) + ... + 2f(x_{n-2}) + 4f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_{n}) \Big)\)

where

\(\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

and

\(\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x\)
hints_latex:
Simpson's Rule in full generality is, for even $\displaystyle n$,

$S_{n} = \frac{\Delta x}{3} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 4f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + 4f(x_3) + ... + 2f(x_{n-2}) + 4f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_{n}) \Big)$

where

$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

and

$\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x$
hints_raw:
Simpson's Rule in full generality is, for even <math> \displaystyle n </math>,

<math>
S_{n} = \frac{\Delta x}{3} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 4f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + 4f(x_3) + ... + 2f(x_{n-2}) + 4f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_{n}) \Big)
</math>

where

<math>
\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}
</math>

and

<math>
\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x
</math>
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
We proceed as suggested by the hint. First notice that

\(\displaystyle \Delta x = (6-2)/4 = 1.\)

Next, notice that

\[\begin{aligned} x_{0} &= 2 + 0\Delta x = 2\\ x_{1} &= 2 + 1\Delta x = 3\\ ...&\\ x_{4} &= 2 + 4\Delta x = 6 \end{aligned}\]

Thus, figuring out the \(f(x_{i})\) terms directly from the graph, we have

\(S_4 = \frac13[3+(4)(8)+(2)(7)+(4)(6)+4] = \frac{77}{3}\)
sols_latex:
We proceed as suggested by the hint. First notice that

$\displaystyle \Delta x = (6-2)/4 = 1.$

Next, notice that

\begin{align*}
x_{0} &= 2 + 0\Delta x = 2\\
x_{1} &= 2 + 1\Delta x = 3\\
...&\\
x_{4} &= 2 + 4\Delta x = 6 
\end{align*}

Thus, figuring out the $f(x_{i})$ terms directly from the graph, we have

$S_4 = \frac13[3+(4)(8)+(2)(7)+(4)(6)+4] = \frac{77}{3}$
sols_raw:
We proceed as suggested by the hint. First notice that

<math> \displaystyle \Delta x = (6-2)/4 = 1. </math>

Next, notice that 

<math>
\begin{align}
x_{0} &= 2 + 0\Delta x = 2\\
x_{1} &= 2 + 1\Delta x = 3\\
...&\\
x_{4} &= 2 + 4\Delta x = 6 
\end{align}
</math>

Thus, figuring out the <math> f(x_{i}) </math> terms directly from the graph, we have

<math> S_4 = \frac13[3+(4)(8)+(2)(7)+(4)(6)+4] = \frac{77}{3} </math>
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Question 1-3 are short-answer questions. Put your answer in the box provided. Simplify your answer as much as possible. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct answer placed in the box. Show your work, for part marks.

Use Simpson’s Rule, with n = 4, to estimate the area under the graph between x = 2 and x = 6.
statement_latex:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Question 1-3 are short-answer
questions. Put your answer in the box provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answer as much as possible}. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct
answer placed in the box. \textbf{Show your work}, for part marks.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH101/April_2013/MATH101April2013Q1ab.jpg}

Use Simpson's Rule, with \emph{n} = 4, to estimate the area under the
graph between \emph{x} = 2 and \emph{x} = 6.
